property.name: text
property.value: Read Moto watch accelerometer via UDP, and if the watch is being held vertically, generate a "raised hand" even.

property.name: runCommand
property.value: @node@ nodeHostInvoke.js node_modules/@accessors-hosts/node/@modelName@

property.name: text
property.value: Authors: Edward A. Lee, Christopher Brooks

property.name: text
property.value: If you have a TerraSwarm account, click here to open up https://www.terraswarm.org/urbanheartbeat/wiki/Main/WatchAndroidStudioSetup

property.name: text
property.value: This demo requires a Moto 360 Watch that has been programmed to run the WatchSensorUDP watchlet. Click here to open up https://github.com/terraswarm/WatchSoftware

property.name: text
property.value: Set the bridgeIP parameter to the address of your Hue bridge. One way to find the IP address is to use nmap: nmap 10.0.0.1/24

property.name: text
property.value: Click on AccessorCodeGenerator to create Node Accessor Host Code and run it locally.

property.name: text
property.value: Set the lightID parameter (an integer). To find out what lights are available to your bridge, examine the "lights" output of the Hue accessor. Look for lights where "reachable" is true.

property.name: text
property.value: Click on AccessorSSHCodeGenerator to create Node Accesso Host Code and run it on a remote machine.

property.name: text
property.value: To run on a SwarmBox, you must have a TerraSwarm account. Click here to open up https://www.terraswarm.org/testbeds/wiki/Main/SbuserSSHAccess

property.name: text
property.value: The SSH code generator uses the @terraswarm/accessors module from npm. So, if you update the accessors, you will need to update @terraswarm/accessors. For details, click here to open https://accessors.org/wiki/Main/NPMUpload

property.name: text
property.value: To run on a SwarmBox, UDP port 4568 must be open Click here to open up the TerraSwarm WatchGestureAccessorDemo page.

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value:
Read sensor data from a Moto 360 watch that is broadcasting the data via UDP on the local network.

FIXME: Give the app that needs to be running on the watch.

Each sensor has its own output port. The outputs will be objects with fields 'watchID', a four-character string, and 'timestamp' representing FIXME: what information is this?

See https://www.terraswarm.org/urbanheartbeat/wiki/Main/WatchSoftware for details on the software that runs on the watch.

property.name: author
property.value: Christopher Brooks and Edward A. Lee

property.name: listeningAddress (port)
property.value: The interface to listen on for incoming messages. This defaults to "0.0.0.0", which means to listen on all network interfaces.

property.name: listeningPort (port)
property.value: The port to listen on for incoming messages. This defaults to 4567.

property.name: message (port)
property.value: The received message as a raw byte array.

property.name: listening (port)
property.value: True to indicate that listening has begun, false to indicate that it has stopped.

property.name: accelerometer (port)
property.value: The accelerometer data from the watch. This is an object with fields x, y, z representing measured acceleration (or the earth's gravitational field, which is indistinguishable from acceleration). These will be in SI units of meters per second squared. The 'z' field points into the watch face, so it will be roughly +9.8 (one g) when the watch is facing up. The 'x' field is transverse to the watch, where +9.8 occurs roughly when 9 o'clock is pointing straight down. The 'y' axis is along band axis, where +9.8 will occur roughly when the 12 o'clock is pointing straight up.

property.name: gyro (port)
property.value: The gyroscope data from the watch. This is an object with fields x, y, z representing measured angular rotation (in radians per second). The 'z' field represents rotation around an axis pointing into the watch face. The 'x' field axis transverse to the watch, and the 'y' axis is along band axis. These are the same axes as for the accelerometer.

property.name: accelerometerSensitivity (parameter)
property.value: If this is set to something other than zero, then this accessor will output accelerometer data only when the accelerometer reading differs in some axis by more than the specified sensitivity. A small number means high sensitivity (lots of outputs) and a larger number means low sensitivity (fewer outputs).

property.name: gyroSensitivity (parameter)
property.value: If this is set to something other than zero, then this gyroscope will output data only when the gyro reading differs in some axis by more than the specified sensitivity. A small number means high sensitivity (lots of outputs) and a larger number means low sensitivity (fewer outputs).

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor

property.name: description
property.value:
This accessor controls a Philips Hue lightbulb via a Hue Bridge. To use it, you need to know the IP address of the Hue Bridge, which is unfortunately, somewhat hard to find out. See below for some hints.

Upon initialization, this accessor will use the userName parameter to contact the Hue Bridge. If the userName is invalid, then the accessor will engage in a dialog with the Bridge to create a new user. This will require the user to push the button on the Hue Bridge when the alert to do so appears. The assigned userName will be recorded in the userName parameter.

Upon authenticating with the Bridge, this accessor will output a data structure that reports all the lights that have been registered with the Bridge. These lights each have a number ID, such as '1'. The state of each light will be reported in this output. The most important property of the state is the 'reachable' property. If this has value false, then the light is not reachable by the Bridge and therefore cannot be controlled.

The commands input is either a single command or an array of commands, where each command can have the following properties:

  • id (required): The id of the light to manipulate, which is a number.
  • on: true to turn on; false to turn off.
  • bri: Brightness. 0-255.
  • hue: Color, for bulbs that support color. This is a number in the range 0-65280.
  • xy: Two numbers between 0.0 and 1.0 in an array, e.g. [0.4, 0.4], specifying a color according to the image at https://www.developers.meethue.com/documentation/core-concepts
  • sat: Saturation, for bulbs that support color. This is a number in the range 0-255.
  • ct: Color temperature. This takes values in a scale called "reciprocal megakelvin" or "mirek". Using this scale, the warmest color 2000K is 500 mirek ("ct":500) and the coldest color 6500K is 153 mirek ("ct":153).
  • transitiontime: The time in ms for the bulb to make the transition.

Please see Hue docs for mapping colors to hue/saturation values: http://www.developers.meethue.com/documentation/core-concepts.

Some common colors given as xy are (for a gammut B bulb):

  • orange: [0.60, 0.38]
  • red: [0.67, 0.32]
  • yellow: [0.54, 0.42]
  • green: [0.41, 0.52]
  • violet: [0.17, 0.04]
  • blue: [0.17, 0.05]
  • magenta: [0.41, 0.18]
  • cool white: [0.28, 0.28] (about 10,000 Kelvin)
  • warm white: [0.46, 0.41] (about 2,700 Kelvin)

If a light is not accessible, this accessor warns but does not error. In CapeCode, this results in a dialog box with a message. Sometimes Hue lights are transient (get unplugged, become temporarily disconnected) and may be valid in the future. Rather than terminating the model, we hope that the lights come back. A good practice is to use the lights output to determine which lights are reachable.

Discovery: Finding the IP address of the Hue Bridge is not necessarily easy. The bridge acquires its address via DHCP, so the address will typically change each time the bridge is rebooted. Moreover, the address will likely not be accessible except on the local network. The bridge responds to UPnP packets (universal plug-and-play), so it is possible to use software such as Cling to discover the bridge. Another option is to use the Discovery accessor and look for a device named philips-hue (or the name assigned to your bridge if assigned manually).

property.name: author
property.value: Edward A. Lee, Marcus Pan, Elizabeth Osyk, Marten Lohstroh

property.name: commands (port)
property.value: JSON commands for the Hue, for example, {"id" : 1, "on" : true, "hue" : 120}

property.name: bridgeIP (port)
property.value: The bridge IP address (and port, if needed).

property.name: userName (parameter)
property.value: The username for logging on to the Hue Bridge. This must be at least 11 characters, or the Hue regards it as invalid. A username will be automatically generated if none is available. The assigned user name will be sent on the assignedUserName output.

property.name: lights (port)
property.value: An object with one property for each light that is registered with the bridge. The name of the property is the light ID, an integer given as a string, and the value is an object with information about the light (manufacturer, modelid, name, state, etc.). The state property has a boolean 'on' indicating whether the light is on and 'reachable' indicating whether the light is in communication with the bridge.

property.name: assignedUserName (port)
property.value: If a user name is automatically generated and registered with the bridge, then it will be sent on this output port.

property.name: bridgeIP (parameter)
property.value: The bridge IP address (and port, if needed).

property.name: probe (port)
property.value: Trigger production of a 'lights' output that gives the status of lights registered with this bridge.

property.name: response (port)
property.value: The response from the bridge to a command.

property.name: onWrapup
property.value: turn off

property.name: script
note
property.value: NOTE: To see the script, invoke Open Actor
